title: Cat. 24  Chelsea Shops, 1888
publication_title: The Lithographs of James McNeill Whistler: The Digital Edition
content:
<section class="osci-tk-epub-section body" id="body"> 241888Way: 20  
Levy: 33  
Transfer lithograph, drawn on coarse-grained transfer paper  
Ink color: black  
Signature: printed butterfly, center right  
Two states; first state image size: 95 × 195 mm; second state image size: 95 × 195 mm  
Number of impressions listed by Way: 17 (without distinguishing two states)  
Printer: Way  
Watermarks: 34, 41, 42, 113, 139, 141, 151, 188, 190, 191, 200, 272–274, 280  
Posthumous edition: 45 impressions printed by Goulding on 3 May 1904  
Posthumous watermarks: 50–56, 70, 101, 104, 106, 116, 130, 131, 169, 171, 189, 202, 211, 219, 220, 226, 300, 312, 313  
Stone: erased in 1904  
Whistler-Way Letters: 25, 34, 35, 84, 86; apps. II.3, II.4, III.2, V.1  
Selected Literature: Pennell (1897), p. 286; Way and Dennis (1903), p. 85  
Lifetime Exhibitions: London 1895–96 (no. 46, as Shops, Chelsea); Chicago 1900b (nos. 16 and 17)

This view of shopfronts in Chelsea is closely related to several etchings, watercolors, and small oils Whistler created in the 1880s and 1890s. Especially close in both vantage point and attention to architectural elements of the old buildings are Chelsea Shops (YMSM 246), Chelsea Houses (YMSM 290), and Carlyle’s Sweetstuff Shop (YMSM 375), all oils on panel of the 1880s. By 1888, when this transfer drawing was made, frontal views of shops and houses had become frequent subjects in Whistler’s work.

The drawing appears to have been executed rapidly, with a light touch, and when first proved it looked very much like a chalk or pencil sketch. After a few impressions had been pulled, Whistler removed most of the hatched shadow above the central doorway, thereby emphasizing the simplicity of the forms. The subject is one of the five drawings (cat. 23, cat. 24, cat. 25, cat. 26, and cat. 27) listed in Way’s invoice as having been transferred and proved on 8 June 1888 (app. II.3 and app. II.4).

Way (1905) recorded only one state of Chelsea Shops, and listed a total of seventeen impressions pulled from the stone, a number that seems to encompass both of the states identified here. However, nineteen impressions can be documented in the correspondence between Whistler and Way (see letter 24, letter 25, letter 34, and letter 86). A further discrepancy exists in the 1903 inventory of Whistler’s estate, where Rosalind Birnie Philip listed five signed and twenty unsigned impressions.

Shading above the central doorway has not yet been removed.

CHICAGO: MWC, grayish ivory chine (126 × 203 mm) mounted on off-white plate paper (278 × 383 mm). LONDON: BM, grayish white chine (125 × 203 mm) mounted on white plate paper (265 × 362 mm). WASHINGTON: FGA, grayish white chine (126 × 203 mm) mounted on white plate paper (278 × 382 mm); NGA, grayish ivory chine (126 × 202 mm) mounted on ivory plate paper (250 × 291 mm).

REMARKS: Another first-state impression is found in Boston, BPL.

The shading on the left two-thirds of the overhang above the central doorway has been removed.

Chicago: AIC, ivory laid paper (203 × 310 mm), signed; Palmer, ivory chine (126 × 205 mm) mounted on off-white plate paper (280 × 379 mm); SC, cream Japanese paper (202 × 277 mm). Glasgow: (19) cream laid paper (203 × 310 mm), signed; cream laid paper (203 × 302 mm); cream laid paper (157 × 260 mm); cream Japanese paper (203 × 318 mm); tan Japanese paper (161 × 308 mm); tan Japanese paper (160 × 310 mm); ivory Japanese paper (210 × 310 mm); ivory laid paper (202 × 310 mm), signed; tan laid paper (206 × 310 mm), signed; cream laid paper (198 × 311 mm), inscribed verso, in Whistler’s hand, with a very small w; cream laid paper (218 × 315 mm); cream laid paper (237 × 287 mm); cream Japanese paper (212 × 312 mm); cream Japanese paper (203 × 278 mm); cream Japanese paper (208 × 313 mm); cream laid paper (202 × 305 mm); cream Japanese paper (202 × 277 mm); cream Japanese paper (201 × 277 mm); cream Japanese paper (201 × 277 mm). Washington: FGA, cream laid paper (204 × 317 mm).

Remarks: Other second-state impressions are found in Boston, MFA; Brooklyn, TBM; and New York, MMA.  
Nesta R. Spink, Harriet K. Stratis, Martha Tedeschi

</section><section epub:type="footnotes" id="footnotes">These works are in the Freer Gallery of Art, Washington, D.C.; Stanford University Museum and Art Gallery; and a private collection.

Rosalind Birnie Philip referred to this subject as Old Houses Chelsea; GUL LB6; transcribed in MacDonald (1988), p. 38. Whistler also seems to have used this title; see app. I.1.

</section><section id="figures">Cat. 24, first state. The Art Institute of Chicago, gift of the Crown Family in honor of James N. Wood, 2004.549.
